snippet: The proliferation of gadgets, apps and Web-based information has given the medical profession a black bag of new tools, Katie Hafner reports in Tuesday's New York Times. Clinicians have new ways to diagnose symptoms and treat patients, to obtain and...
abstract: The proliferation of gadgets, apps and Web-based information has given the medical profession a black bag of new tools, Katie Hafner reports in Tuesday's New York Times. Clinicians have new ways to diagnose symptoms and treat patients, to obtain and share information, to think about what it means to be both a doctor and a patient.

headline.main: Daily Report: Mobile Devices Change Doctors' Rounds
